awd_titl_txt: Topographic response to the transition from snowmelt- to rainfall- triggered extremes
awd_abstract_narration:
In September of 2013, a "1000-yr" storm occurred in the foothills of the mountains near Boulder, CO, triggering widespread landslides and floods. However, the causal chain from extreme rainfall to flooding to river erosion and landslides is complex. For example, this event produced "25- to 200- yr" floods and landslides locally removed 100's to 1000's of years of sediment production. This project focuses on how the two main modes of runoff generation (snowmelt and rainfall runoff) in mountain landscapes can lead to diagnostic differences in the rates and patterns of erosional processes. We use the Colorado Front Range, USA as a case study where mean runoff systematically increases with elevation due to increased snowmelt, while peak runoff is highest at intermediate elevations caused by large, intense rainfall events. Better accounting for elevation-dependent runoff generation has implications for water resource management, flood and erosion hazard assessment, and landscape evolution modeling. To this end, this project fosters collaboration among three institutes at the University of Colorado, Boulder (the Boulder Creek Critical Zone Observatory, Earth Lab, and the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System) to better integrate data collection, analysis, and model development via open, reproducible workflows made available to researchers, decision-makers, and citizens.

The main goals of this project are to develop a quantitative framework for river incision that accounts for two well-documented attributes of the Colorado Front Range: (1) an orographic transition from snowmelt- to rainfall- triggered extreme events, and (2) the formation and persistence of high elevation, low relief, erosion surfaces, into which bedrock river canyons have incised.  While the Colorado Front Range is the focus, the approach is transferable to other settings with strong orographic gradients in event-scale runoff variability (e.g., Andes; Himalayas). To accomplish objectives, research tasks consist of three main components: (A) Hydroclimatic data analysis; (B) Topographic data analysis; (C) Numerical modeling of river incision. Hydroclimatic data analysis focuses on how sub-daily to daily (i.e., intensity, duration) and spatial (i.e., storm size) attributes of rainfall and snowmelt events imprint into flood frequencies. Topographic data analysis focuses on quantifying how channel steepness, channel width, and grain size distributions vary in the landscape based on data from field surveys and photogrammetry, high-resolution airborne lidar topography along Boulder Creek and the Rampart Range, and moderate-resolution regional topography. Numerical modeling of river incision builds on a 1-D stochastic-threshold model of bedrock incision, that currently only includes stochastic runoff intensity, by adding more stochastic parameters (i.e., the location and spatial footprint of runoff generation). Explicit accounting for orographic gradients in rainfall and snowmelt statistics and their role in setting the timescale of river response to base level fall provides a first test of a previously unrecognized feedback between climate, topography, and erosion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of extreme events (e.g., river floods, landslides) has long motivated inquiry into land surface dynamics. The Colorado Front Range, USA is a unique setting to test the causes and consequences of rare runoff events for two main reasons: (1) mean water supply is largely set by snowmelt at higher elevations while historically significant floods are largely sourced from rainfall runoff at lower mountain elevations, and (2) late Cenozoic base level fall has led to the incomplete migration of slope-break knickpoints along river profiles leaving a spatially extensive high elevation, low relief surface. In this project, we set out to understand whether the relatively slow migration of river knickpoints might be explained by orographic gradients in the efficiency of erosional processes. Specifically, we wanted to interrogate why intense runoff events are favored at low to intermediate elevations. Our analysis both corroborated some classic ideas and yielded a few surprises.

Analysis of daily streamflow data largely corroborated prior studies on flood frequency in the Colorado Front Range, showing that the right tails of runoff distributions are indeed triggered by rainstorms at low to intermediate mountain elevations. However, we also discovered that orographic patterns in runoff statistics are not a simple reflection of spatial patterns in sub-daily rainfall statistics. Instead, orographic gradients in runoff appear to follow differences in hillslope architecture, leading us to hypothesize that rockier hillsides adjacent to incised river networks can generate more runoff for a given rainstorm event because of their reduced water storage capacity. In the Rampart Range, a portion of the Colorado Front Range that was not glaciated, we used airborne lidar and drone photogrammetry to map the occurrence of bedrock outcrop in greater detail. In addition to constraining the strong elevation dependence on bedrock exposure, we also found that topographic aspect is of similar importance. The elevation dependence on soil patchiness tracks with the downstream to upstream migration of knickpoints responding to higher rates of base level fall. In contrast, we argue that the aspect dependence may be driven by differences in long-term soil production rates, whereby equatorial facing slopes exhibit lower soil production rates with rockier surfaces. We invoke a humped soil production function, where soil production rates peak at some non-zero soil depth, to help explain landscape scale patterns in surface properties. Specifically, we developed a new Individual-Based Model of forest dynamics that provides an alternative way to simulate soil production that can be validated both against topographical and ecological constraints. 

This project was instrumental in enabling an early-career Principal Investigator to conduct independent research under the mentorship and collaboration of three accomplished scientists. A key contribution of this work was in the development of new open-source software for accuracy assessment of classified data, bedrock river incision modeling, and soil production and transport modeling. Following best practices for data management and computing, insights and models developed from this project are readily accessible to future researchers. Data analysis and landscape evolution models associated with this project also serve as the basis for educational materials disseminated by the Earth Lab and Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System communities.
